title: Black Glass Bargain
description: In a lanternless corner of the Archive of Veins where the marrow-ink shelves breathe like sleeping animals, Sila Vane waits with a black mirror shard turned face-down like a guilty coin, its edge catching only the faintest tremor of lume oil from a distant scribe alcove. She speaks of the Nameskeeper as one speaks of a tide you cannot see but must bind your life to, a pull that has sold assassinations dressed as accidents and revolutions disguised as accounting entries. Tonight the tide wants to sell a legend to the Saltglass Syndicate, and with it the city’s skin, its price measured in cullet and choir-silenced witnesses, unless someone steals back a page for the second time and does it so loudly that even Triarchs must pretend surprise for the sake of ceremony. The Watch tightens cordons beyond the Archive doors and the echo-pipes carry soft whistle-codes that taste like iron on the tongue; Serge Kobb walks his men as if sleep were a rumor and duty a fever that will not break. Sila offers Rogan a ledger fragment that names ‘O.V.’ more openly than rumor would dare, and asks him to keep her alive between the Nameskeeper’s smile and the Syndicate’s furnace heat, between the Watch’s oaths and a mirror that refuses to blink. Every ally is a splinter, every splinter a key that fits a lock you did not know was in your chest, and somewhere beneath the floorbones the Resonant Gate’s low hum threads the dark like a promise the city is too tired to keep. By dawn, either proof will drink the light and ring the Hall of Mirrors like a struck bowl, or it will be burned into ash and scattered across the rumor-streets where truth runs on bleeding feet.
objectives: Meet Sila Vane at the Archive and agree on the terms of protection.
Infiltrate the black file stacks and locate the Nameskeeper’s drop point.
Evade or negotiate with Serge Kobb and his Watch unit without bloodshed.
Secure the ledger page naming Orun Ves and escape via an echo-pipe service tunnel.
Choose whether to give the page to Isha, Nyra, or keep a secret copy for leverage.

dialogue.speaker: Sila Vane
dialogue.lines: I don’t expect forgiveness, Rogan Kettlebone, only a transaction measured in saved throats rather than cut ones, and I know the difference as a butcher knows a bone seam. The Nameskeeper keeps his hands clean by making everyone else wear gloves, and he launders our sins in other people’s memories so the stains never stick to our own. He has arranged a sale tonight, something bright enough to dazzle the Syndicate into paying with favors they cannot retract, and if it closes, the city’s ribs will creak to a tune counted in tariffs. Take this shard, face-down, and this route stitched through the Archive’s blind veins where the marrow-ink does not whisper names out loud when the Hall of Mirrors listens. By morning, either we have a city that can blush at its own reflection, or we will have a story amputated at the shoulder and taught to walk on rumor like a beggar on stilts.

dialogue.speaker: Rogan Kettlebone
dialogue.lines: I’ve protected worse people for better reasons and better people for reasons I still cannot say without tasting dust, and that’s the city’s math when water is short and oaths are long. If you place a page in my hand that can hold a man to his own name under the mirror-oculus, I’ll carry you between blades and badges as if you were my last canteen in a glassstorm. I know the Nameskeeper’s tricks like I know the feel of a mooring chain singing under my palms; you can ride that song, but it will take a finger if you pretend it isn’t sharp. If you are lying to me, I will make your mirror show your face until you crack from the inside, and I will shepherd the shards to someone who still believes in right angles. But if you are telling the truth, we will pry the gate of this night with a fulgurite edge and teach the dawn to come on command.

dialogue.speaker: Sila Vane
dialogue.lines: I have lived with my face long enough to map the rivers where fear runs and the deltas where it dries to salt, and I am done pretending the taste doesn’t burn the tongue. I want to put a new crack in a different face tonight, a letter-shaped flaw that makes lies leak in public. The Nameskeeper thinks in mirrors, but I have learned to think in shadows where reflections forget to hunt, and in shadows we can make two copies when one was ordered. I will walk behind you and to the left where a Watchman’s eyes forget to look, and I will not reach for anything but the page until my fingers have it, and then I will move like ink runs downhill. Believe this much: I am not looking to live forever, only long enough to see the right man swear under the oculus with the city listening.

dialogue.speaker: Serge Kobb
dialogue.lines: This is the part where I say stop and you pretend to, and then I decide whether to honor our old habits or my new orders as they grind their teeth in my pocket. You pull at this thread in the Archive and the coat won’t just fray; it will burst at the seams and leave a city shivering on the ribline, and I will be the one blamed for the draft. I have men who have not slept since the Aerie chain sang wrong three nights ago, and they will do as I say even if it makes them throw up later in their helmets. Make me believe your blade knows where to cut, and that it will shave infection without opening an artery that carries our ration permits. Talk to me like I do not enjoy being the hinge on this door, because I don’t, and tell me why I should leave it unlatched for one more night when the storm is already rattling it off the frame.

dialogue.speaker: Rogan Kettlebone
dialogue.lines: If we don’t cut now, Serge, the rot climbs to the heartseed, and then the winter warmth the city prays to turns fever-hot and the ribs we love become a kiln for our mistakes. This isn’t a hungry man stealing a loaf under a shadecloth; this is a man at the top of the table deciding what degree of hunger keeps him seated while the rest kneel. I won’t draw on your men and I won’t shame them in front of your whistles, but I will go through this door because the city needs to hear one true name said without tremor. Let me pass and I will carry your name folded into the page’s margin, and when the Hall of Mirrors hums, I will say that Serge Kobb chose the city over the clerk-chain and left blood where it belonged—inside. Turn me back, and the Nameskeeper sells silence to the Syndicate, and tomorrow you’ll be issuing curfews to protect a lie that will starve people you’ve sworn to keep breathing.

dialogue.speaker: Sila Vane
dialogue.lines: Footsteps on the other side, regular as a tax drum, which means we are out of grace and into math, so take the page and the prepared copy and move like a shadow when the lumen flares. The Nameskeeper thinks in mirrors, so think in negative space, the place a mirror cannot see because it confuses it with itself; that is where we leave the decoy. We will pass the black file stacks where the erased names hum when you breathe wrong, and we will not hum back because the Archive eats singers. Two truths are better than one because a single truth can be strangled by the first pair of hands to find it, but two truths make a strangler use both hands and leave the city free to run. Keep your whistle close and your rope closer; if we fall, let it be into the echo-pipes where sound travels faster than regret.

dialogue.speaker: Isha Velroon
dialogue.lines: The Hall of Mirrors will not like what its walls must hear, but those walls were raised to catch the weight of truth as well as the weight of ceremony, and I have polished them for both. If this ink holds, the city will sway like a pilgrim on the Sighing Steps at the thousand-and-first truth, and I will put my shoulder to you so you do not fall while it speaks. Know that the Order will be accused of hungers it does not possess, and of kindnesses it has not yet earned, and I will still stand, because mercy without courage is a bowl with no bottom. Place the page on the mirror floor and say the name without malice, for malice stains even righteous indictments, and we must let the light, not our anger, do the cutting. When the echoes return, I will shelter you beneath the oculus, and if the Watch comes heavy, they will have to step on my robe to reach you, and that will be their sermon to answer for.

dialogue.speaker: Professor Nyra Vale
dialogue.lines: The ink sings like a cut tooth when I breathe across it, a thin keen that matches the Gate’s sixth harmonic, and that is a song liars cannot carry without their pitch warping in the mirror. It will not be easy to deny because its marrow-ink binds to three signatures like a braid, and one of them has the tremor of the Magistrate’s absent sleep. Bring it under the ethics lamp and we will read it with the dead as witnesses, for contracts are not alive until memory consents to carry them. Be ready, though: a cornered man will knock down pillars he swore to uphold just to have something to lean on while he falls, and you will be asked to choose whether to brace the hall or let him take the load alone. If you place the page with us, the Unentombed will keep it cold and true, and we will call it back into the city’s mouth when the time is precise instead of merely loud.

dialogue.speaker: Rogan Kettlebone
dialogue.lines: I’ve got the page and a copy tucked where mirrors don’t shine and where Night-Glass hands won’t fit without losing fingers, and I’ve counted the ways this goes wrong more times than the Watch’s whistle-chain. Tomorrow we speak it, either under the mirror-oculus with prayers listening or under the ethics lamp with the dead looking on, and either way the sound will travel farther than my name ever deserved. Tonight we sleep with one eye open, a whistle by the bed, and a rope looped around the ankle because dreams are drop shafts and the Nameskeeper knows every rung. I have walked ribs in storms and heard the city hum a note only children and hounds can hear, and that is how this feels: like the long omen before a hard season. If we fail, the page becomes ash and rumor; if we succeed, the page becomes a spine and the lie bends on it until it breaks.

choices.title: Lay the Page Before Isha Velroon and the Hollow Sun
choices.text: You carry the page to the Temple of the Hollow Sun at first light, sand still in your boots and echo-pipe dust clinging to your throat. Isha meets you at the mirror-oculus with eyes that weigh both mercy and cost, and you feel how heavy the robe is when it is made of people’s hopes. You speak Factor Orun Ves’s name with no venom and lay the ledger where light can cool it, and every reliquary hums as if bones remember debts paid late. The Order’s advocates begin their slow careful steps, not to smother the flame but to shield it from gusts that would turn it to wildfire, and you accept that caution is not always cowardice. The Watch’s whispers follow like rook shadows, and the Night-Glass quiets in the rafters, unsure whether to applaud or hide their hands.
choices.outcome: The temple convenes a public hearing beneath the Hall of Mirrors, and while the Syndicate’s counsellors spread sand on the mirror floor to dull the light, Isha insists on water instead and the oculus does not dim. Serge Kobb’s unit holds the cordon but lets witnesses pass, shaping a truth that arrives without stones and leaves without blood, and your name is murmured like a cup passed hand to hand. The Order binds interim protections around you and Sila Vane, not as absolution but as acknowledgment that whistle-blowers bleed easiest, and patrol routes near the Archive bend to leave you blind turns. The Night-Glass Brotherhood loses face in the short term, their legend of untouchability smudged by a confession they did not script, yet their debt to you becomes a corridor that opens when louder doors close. Factor Orun Ves does not fall at once, but the mirror remembers him every time he speaks in council, and each word now pushes against the oculus like a swimmer who knows the lake is watching.

choices.title: Entrust the Page to Professor Nyra Vale and the Unentombed
choices.text: You descend into the Hall of the Unentombed where breath is counted and memory wears its best manners, the page wrapped in cloth that once knew prayer. Nyra guides you to the ethics lamp, its light soft and ungilded, and you unfold the ledger before witnesses who have no pulses but keep perfect time. You speak the name quietly so the dead can hear it first, because they are the city’s long hearing, and the ink’s song threads the room with a chill that tastes like clean water. The Unentombed bind the page to three testimonies, none living, so no blade can silence them without confessing to murder, and that is a calculus the Syndicate can count. You leave through a vertebra side-door while echo-wires carry a message to a judge who still believes that law is a scaffold for mercy, and outside the air feels like the city exhaled without permission.
choices.outcome: The Unentombed preserve the evidence and stagger its revelation, timing each disclosure to star-metal calendars and civic anniversaries so the impact shatters carefully instead of explosively, and the city’s fractures become planned seams. The Watch grumbles that you have chosen scholars over soldiers, yet Serge Kobb’s best sergeant begins sending you quiet routes because the dead told her grandfather’s name in a dream that felt like law. The Hollow Sun frowns at being bypassed, but Isha’s private letter admits that truth’s journey matters more than the banner it carries, and a courteous rivalry replaces outright resistance. Night-Glass agents sniff around the Hall and find their mirrors fogged; their Nameskeeper calculates, realizes leverage has shifted, and shelves the sale with a curse you are never meant to hear. When the page finally rings in public, it comes bracketed by ancestral testimony, bone cords, and a city ready to hear, and Orun Ves’s denials slide off like oil on glass because the dead do not negotiate.

choices.title: Keep a Secret Copy and Play the Long Game
choices.text: You stage the swap loud enough to rattle the cage lamps and leave boot prints on the Archive rules, but in the echo-pipe’s throat you cradle a second page where no mirror looks. You pass a sanitized extract to a clerk who will carry it to both temple and tribunal, a banner without the pole, while the true spine sleeps in your vambrace. Sila sees only what you let her see and thanks you with a look that could be gratitude or a ledger entry, and you nod because both are useful and both can go bad. You send a rook-feathered signal to Zexi Orr to watch the Aerie for Syndicate overreach and you spend a long hour counting favors like canteens before a march. At dusk you drink from your Gate-Blessed canteen and practice saying nothing so well it sounds like a hymn.
choices.outcome: Leverage buys time and time buys angles; the Watch’s blind route through the Archive remains intact because Serge Kobb has plausible deniability, and your shadow grows too complicated to arrest cleanly. Night-Glass owes you one narrow corridor and pays it twice, once with a door opening during a curfew and once with a warning that arrives a day before you need it, and both feel like someone else’s luck. The Syndicate does not fall, but it wobbles, and Factor Orun Ves begins to talk too much at council, filling gaps that did not exist before, and each word is a brick he lays on his own chest. Isha and Nyra each receive enough truth to act without control, and though they bristle, they also stay their sharpest knives because the city needs the page more than it needs to punish you for holding it. The Nameskeeper marks you as a variable instead of an asset, which is safer than it sounds for a time, until the day he needs a legend to burn his name brighter; on that day your rope will matter and the choices you made tonight will decide whether it holds.

rewards.description: Full ledger page naming Factor Orun Ves in the Gate tuning scheme.
Fragile pact with Sila Vane; Night-Glass owes you one narrow corridor.
Watch blind route through the Archive courtesy of Serge Kobb’s discretion.
